summary: Rolando Masferrer was a Cuban exile figure involved in various activities, including plotting against the Haitian government. He had connections to the CIA, as evidenced by concerns over potential damage to CIA activities in Miami due to his planned Haitian invasion and subsequent legal issues. Documents suggest the CIA was concerned about his trial and potential recruitment efforts. There are also allegations of CIA involvement in his assassination. He was a former Cuban senator. The documents span from 1960 to 1976, indicating a long period of involvement in anti-Castro and other activities. The documents suggest a pattern of involvement in covert operations and potential connections to the CIA, as well as scrutiny from the FBI.
significance: The documents suggest that Rolando Masferrer was a figure of interest to both the CIA and FBI, particularly in the context of Cuban exile activities and potential covert operations. While the documents do not directly link him to the JFK assassination, his involvement with the CIA and the Cuban exile community, as well as allegations of CIA involvement in his assassination, could be relevant in understanding the broader context of anti-Castro activities and potential motivations of various actors during that period. The documents also suggest that he was involved in plotting against the Haitian government.
